author: vors
body:
<!-- PR checklist -->
- [ ] Resolves #xyz.
- [x] Code is up-to-date with `master`.
- [ ] Add tests that fail without your changes.
- [x] Update all relevant [documentation](../docs).

<!-- Provide more details about the PR below -->

comments.author: ghost
comments.body: @vors @joeyaiello I think we should have a style guide, in the docs repo, that should be linked to in this section. I think having one line about style seems somewhat random here.

comments.author: andschwa
comments.body:
I think this is reasonable.

@eslesar isn't the docs repo for PowerShell _consumers_? I believe the consensus was to keep developer docs in one place, next to the code, in this repo, and style guides definitely fall under developer docs.

comments.author: ghost
comments.body:
I don't know of any such consensus that was reached regarding developer docs in this repo.

Either way, if there is going to be a style guide in this repo, that's fine, but this doc is pretty lean, and I don't think we should try to include style here. Just my opinion.

comments.author: joeyaiello
comments.body:
@andschwa @eslesar Yes, that's true that the docs that are supposed to exist in this repository are specifically for people who are contributing in some way to the `PowerShell/PowerShell` project. 

However, I think @eslesar's point is that, if the style guide for dev docs vs. user docs is the same, why not simply link between them?

comments.author: vors
comments.body:
I agree with @eslesar, and we probably should borrow this line into PowerShell-Docs repo at some point. At the moment, almost all markdown in PowerShell-Docs violates this rule, so there is more work to put it there, then just copying.

I'm going to merge this PR, because I encounter cases, when I need to refer people to this sentence.

title: Add note about one sentance per line to CONTRIBUTING.md
